questions.text: Which of the following GAG has anticoagulant activity
questions.explanation:
GAG

Predominantly Found In

Hyaluronic acid

Synovial fluid, vitreous humor, connective tissues

Chondroitin sulfate

Cartilage, tendons, ligaments, bone, skin

Dermatan sulfate

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves, tendons, lungs

Heparan sulfate

Basement membranes, cell surfaces, liver, lung, kidney

Keratan sulfate

Cornea, cartilage, bone, connective tissues, brain

Heparin

Mast cells, liver, lung, intestinal mucosa, blood (as a medication)

GAG

Function

Hyaluronic acid

Provides hydration and viscoelasticity to tissues

Chondroitin sulfate

Provides structural support to cartilage and other connective tissues

Dermatan sulfate

Present in skin and blood vessels, contributes to their structure

Heparan sulfate

Acts as a co-receptor for various growth factors and cytokines

Keratan sulfate

Helps maintain corneal transparency

Heparin

Acts as an anticoagulant, inhibits blood clotting

questions.text: Which of the following glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are responsible for corneal transparency?
questions.explanation:
Mucopolysaccharide

Primary Locations

Functions

Hyaluronic Acid (Option D)

Connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, vitreous humor

Serves as a lubricant in joint cavities and contributes to the structure of connective tissues

Heparin (Option C)

Liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes

Acts as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inactivates thrombin and other clotting factors

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option B)

Cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, skin

Provides structural support to connective tissues and contributes to their resilience and elasticity

Keratan Sulfate (Option A)

Cornea, cartilage

  

Dermatan Sulfate

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves

Contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves

questions.text: Which of the following options is correct with respect to a fed state? 1. Insulin secretion is more 2. Glucagon secretion is less 3. Insulin secretions is less 4. Glucagon secretion is more
questions.explanation:
• Fed or anabolic state occurs immediately after a meal when the energy of nutrients (carbohydrate, protein, or fat) is transferred to high energy compounds for immediate use or for storage. Peripheral tissues (predominantly skeletal muscle) buffer ingested glucose by storing it as glycogen.
  • Fasted or catabolic state occurs later when the level of available nutrients decreases in the blood, and the stored reserves (initially glycogen) are mobilized to perform work or to generate heat. During prolonged fasting, fat oxidation and ketone bodies are used to meet whole body energy requirements.

questions.text: Complex IV is inhibited by?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Topic

Information

Complex IV

Complex IV, also known as cytochrome c oxidase, is the final enzyme in the electron transport chain located in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyses the transfer of electrons from cytochrome c to molecular oxygen, generating water and producing a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Cyanide

Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV. It binds to the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase and prevents the transfer of electrons to molecular oxygen, thereby blocking the electron transport chain and halting oxidative phosphorylation. Cyanide poisoning can result in rapid cell death due to the cessation of ATP production. It causes histotoxic hypoxia.

Mechanism of inhibition

Cyanide binds to the ferric (Fe3+) form of the heme group in cytochrome c oxidase and converts it to the ferrous (Fe2+) form, which has a higher affinity for oxygen. This prevents the transfer of electrons from cytochrome c to oxygen, effectively halting the electron transport chain.

Clinical significance

Cyanide poisoning can occur through inhalation, ingestion, or absorption through the skin. Symptoms of cyanide poisoning include headache, dizziness, confusion, respiratory distress, and coma. Treatment typically involves administration of antidotes such as hydroxocobalamin, which binds to cyanide and forms a stable complex that is excreted in the urine.

Use in research

Cyanide is commonly used in research as a tool to study Complex IV function and the electron transport chain. Inhibiting Complex IV with cyanide can be used to study the downstream effects of oxidative phosphorylation inhibition, such as changes in ATP production, cellular metabolism, and gene expression.
